Award.AwardTitle: Combining Algal and Plant Photosynthesis (CAPP2): Application to Extend the NSF/BBSRC PSIL Collaboration
Award.AbstractNarration:
Productivity in many crops is limited by CO2 availability and water use. The CAPP project aims to overcome those limitations by transferring a performance-enhancing Carbon Concentrating Mechanism (CCM) from green algae to higher plants. This project will yield significant advances in our understanding in the function of CCMs, which remain mysterious even though nearly all algae use them to assimilate CO2. If successful, the project will be a key step towards significant increases in crop productivity. More generally, this project represents one of the first attempts at transplanting a complex system from one organism to another, and thus will present many opportunities for learning general principles that will be useful as mankind increasingly attempts to engineer biology.

CAPP2 will focus on understanding the pyrenoid, an organelle at the core of the algal CCM, and re-creating its key features in the C3 plant Arabidopsis. Structure, assembly and regulation of the pyrenoid will be studied in the green alga Chlamydomonas, using mutants, light and electron microscopy, and biochemistry. Components will be introduced into Arabidopsis, and the impact on productivity will be modeled and measured. Additionally, a FÃ¶rster Resonance Energy Transfer (FRET) nanosensor will be developed to measure concentrations of bicarbonate with sub-cellular resolution in vivo; the sensor will be applied to characterize the CCM in both Chlamydomonas and Arabidopsis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background

Alleviating food insecurity is a major challenge for the present century. Novel strategies are needed to increase crop productivity, as yields of several of our grain crops, including rice and wheat, are plateauing. One strategy is to try to overcome the inefficiencies of the enzyme responsible for >99% of the Planet’s assimilation of carbon dioxide (CO2) into organic matter, Rubisco. Rubisco is slow and most land plants require large amounts of the enzyme to support photosynthesis. Micro-algae found ways to accelerate Rubisco activity whilst minimizing investments into the enzyme by operating a Carbon-Concentrating Mechanism (CCM). Algal CCMs make use of the high concentrations of bicarbonate ions in the oceans, converting them to CO2 in close proximity of Rubisco. Key to the process is the packaging of Rubisco alongside a carbonic anhydrase inside a micro-compartment, called a pyrenoid. This successful evolutionary adaptation, first discovered 40 years ago, is responsible for nearly one third of the Planet’s net primary production. However, rapid progress in resolving the molecular details of the algal CCM have until recently been hampered by a lack of genetically mapped mutant libraries and high-throughput phenotyping tools.

Aims and objectives

The Combining Algal and Plant Photosynthesis (CAPP) project has two main objectives: (a) apply novel methods to try to identify all the components of the algal CCM and associated pyrenoid; (b) test whether an algal CCM can be expressed in a higher plant (this objective was pursued by our UK partner). CAPP therefore seeks to provide a step change in our fragmentary understanding of one of the most efficient photosynthetic processes on Earth and to provide a proof of concept that land plant photosynthesis can be re-engineered with algal components.

 Key accomplishments

1. We developed a high-throughput pipeline for the systematic localization and mapping of protein-protein interaction networks in the model green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. We published the results for 146 fluorescently tagged proteins, and the spatial interactome of 38 CCM-related proteins (Mackinder et al., 2017, Cell 171, 133-147; doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.08.044). The tagging constructs and transgenic algal strains are now being used by the community for a broad range of purposes ranging from reference fluorescence microscopy of organellar markers to affinity tags for immunoprecipitating protein complexes. Detailed results included:

1.1. We identified 29 distinct sub-cellular localization patterns that represent nearly all of the known organelles and cellular structures. We also demonstrated that several CCM components (two candidate inorganic carbon transporters and a carbonic anhydrase) had been previously mis-localized. This led to a revision of the prevailing CCM paradigm and encouraged the search for novel transporter candidates.

1.2. We discovered that at least 89 different proteins are implicated in the pyrenoid, arranged in 6 six distinct localization patterns, and identified numerous novel Rubisco interactors. The spatial and physical interaction data of pyrenoid proteins provide a roadmap that will allow us and colleagues in the field to characterize the structure, biogenesis, and function of the various sub-compartments of the pyrenoid.

2. We isolated novel CCM mutants through a robotized high-throughput screen of >100,000 insertional mutants. After a secondary microscopy screen, we found that several of these mutants had a pyrenoid phenotype. This lead to the characterization of what we believe is the key linker protein that holds Rubisco together in the pyrenoid matrix, an intrinsically unstructured repeat protein we called Essential Pyrenoid Component 1 (Mackinder et al., 2016, Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A 113, 5958-5963; doi:10.1073/pnas.1522866113).

3. The project also yielded unexpected discoveries. Using Fluorescence Recovery After Photobleaching, we discovered that the Rubisco matrix mixes internally on a time scale of minutes, providing the first ever evidence that the pyrenoid matrix is liquid-like, rather than a crystalline solid. This result, combined with our discovery that the matrix partially dissolves into the surrounding chloroplast during every cell division, convinced us that the Chlamydomonas pyrenoid matrix behaves as a phase-separated, liquid-like non-membrane compartment similar to C. elegans P granules and Xenopus oocyte nucleoli (Freeman Rosenzweig et al., 2017, Cell 171, 148-162; doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.08.008). The pyrenoid is thus an important addition to an emerging paradigm in cellular biology, that cells organize many of their biochemical reactions in liquid-like compartments.

Impact

The CAPP project impacts our understanding of photosynthetic CO2 assimilation. The scientific community and Ag-industry are now better informed to embark on re-engineering approaches to increase plant productivity. The project also had significant impacts on the career development of its participants. Nearly a dozen undergraduate, PhD and postdocs have received a wide training in plant integrative biology. It also provided a stepping stone for one of our Posdocs, who was recently appointed Lecturer at the University of York, where he is running his own research group, still focusing on the pyrenoid. The project also promoted a strong and ongoing working with our UK academic partners in Cambridge, Edinburgh and Norwich.
